results.headline: Ordinary People With Extraordinary Stories

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Primo Levi's Journey

results.summary_short: Vividly impressionistic and delightfully curious, “Primo Levi’s Journey” retraces the writer’s arduous return from a liberated Auschwitz to his home in Italy.

results.headline: Helpful Hints for Saving the Planet

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The 11th Hour

results.summary_short: It appears that the news that we are killing ourselves with our garbage hasn’t sunk in. That’s one reason “The 11th Hour” is such essential viewing.

results.headline: Things That Go Burble in the Night

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Them

results.summary_short: The movie “Them” revels in atmosphere, using long unbroken takes and ambient sound to lull you into complacency before unleashing nerve-jangling shocks.

results.headline: A Bratty American Star in Bollywood

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Marigold

results.summary_short: In “Marigold,” the first United States-India co-production, India provides one of its biggest stars, gorgeous scenery and even the daughter of a Nobel Prize winner.

results.headline: Kong-Heads for Life
results.display_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters

results.summary_short: “The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters,” Seth Gordon’s documentary about two men vying for the high score in Donkey Kong, succeeds as a portrait of a subculture.

results.headline: Pod People Propagating With a Fierce Indigestion

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Invasion

results.summary_short: The latest and lamest version of Don Siegel’s 1956 pulp classic “Invasion of the Body Snatchers”  might have been an accidental camp classic if its politics weren’t so abhorrent.

results.headline: Death ’n’ Yucks, Hallucinogens ’n’ Stiff Upper Lips

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Death at a Funeral

results.summary_short: “Death at a Funeral” stands apart from other movies with rude humor because its characters are determined to keep a stiff upper lip no matter what.

results.headline: Something Is Very Rotten in the City of São Paulo

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Manda Bala (Send A Bullet)

results.summary_short: “Manda Bala” (“Send a Bullet”), a flashy documentary about corruption, injustice and frog farming in Brazil, is a weird hybrid of political exposé and sensationalistic fluff.

results.headline: Along Both Sides of the Velvet Rope, Shallowness Reigns Supreme

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Delirious

results.summary_short: Tom DiCillo’s angry comedy “Delirious” subjects modern celebrity culture to a microscopic examination that shows the toxic virus of fame squirming under its lens.

results.headline: He’s Doing Whatever a Zebra Can

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zebraman

results.summary_short: A downtrodden schoolteacher, a disabled boy and a government agent suffering from an embarrassing itch are the unlikely heroes of “Zebraman.”

results.headline: Facing a Stark Reality, She Decides on a Raffle of Her Only Salable Asset

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love for Sale

results.summary_short:
“Love for Sale” has a deep sympathy for sexual free
spirits in a rigid macho society.

results.headline: A Werewolf War in Need of a Silver Bullet

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Skinwalkers

results.summary_short: Splitting hairs both morally and literally, this human-inhuman hybrid movie pits good werewolves against bad — even if the distinction is fuzzier than their hides.

results.headline: ‘You Go, Girl,’ as Translated Into Hindi

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chak De! India

results.summary_short: Those fondly recalling the United States soccer team’s first-place finish in the 1991 Women’s World Cup will find a lot to like in “Chak De! India.”

results.headline: Comprenez-Vous Woody Allen Films? Here’s a Paris Version

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 2 Days in Paris

results.summary_short: In “2 Days in Paris,” Julie Delpy’s and Adam Goldberg’s performances are so assured and spontaneous that they don’t even seem to be acting.

results.headline: A Date Goes Terribly Wrong. Now It’s Time to Return the Favor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Descent

results.summary_short: With “Descent,” first-time feature filmmaker Talia Lugacy explores the psychic aftershocks of a rape. The movie is hard to watch but essential to see.

results.headline: When Stars (Celestial) Fall, and Stars (Hollywood) Fly

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stardust

results.summary_short: “Stardust” is a sprawling, effects-laden fairy tale with the thundering stamina of a marathon horse race.

results.headline: It’s Tucker vs. Chan, Round 3

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rush Hour 3

results.summary_short: The junky, clunky, grimly unfunny “Rush Hour 3” isn’t the worst movie of the summer. But it’s an enervating bummer nonetheless.

results.headline: A Boy Rendered Speechless by Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rocket Science

results.summary_short: Jeffrey Blitz’s tender but hardheaded “Rocket Science” plumbs the tormented consciousness of a fragile teenager with a paralyzing speech impediment.

results.headline: A Defector’s Second Life, Embracing North Korea

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crossing the Line

results.summary_short: “Crossing the Line” tells of four American servicemen who defected to North Korea, with a focus on Joseph Dresnok, who became a privileged North Korean citizen.

results.headline: Two Brothers, One Down and One Out

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dans Paris

results.summary_short: With “Dans Paris,” Christophe Honoré picks up where the early François Truffaut and his comrades-in-cinema left off — with a playful, liberatory style, and a song in his heart.
